question_details.title: Will the Department of Justice announce an investigation or prosecution of a Democrat who served as president, vice president, congressional leader, whip, or impeachment manager before 2026?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2025-01-31 20:49:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/34514). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

During his 2024 presidential campaign, Donald Trump [<u>repeatedly vowed to pursue investigations and prosecutions against political opponents</u>](https://www.foxnews.com/media/trump-addresses-concerns-he-would-seek-retribution-i-would-have-every-right-go-after-them?msockid=1772840357ba6b8c2861908256286a1f). question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question will resolve as Yes if [<u>credible sources</u>](https://www.metaculus.com/faq/#definitions) report that the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) announces a new investigation or prosecution of a high-profile Democrat, which is for purposes of this question defined as an individual who meets any of the following criteria before January 1, 2026:

\- Has served as Democratic President or Vice President of the United States.

\- Has held any of the following leadership roles in the House of Representatives or Senate (Speaker of the House or House Minority/Democratic Leader, Senate Majority or Minority/Democratic Leader, House or Senate Majority/Democratic Whip).

-Has served as an impeachment manager during either of the impeachment proceedings against Donald Trump (2019–2020 or 2020–2021). The 2019-2020 impeachment managers were Adam Schiff, Jerry Nadler, Zoe Lofgren, Hakeem Jeffries, Val Demings, Sylvia Garcia, and Jason Crow. The 2020-2021 impeachment managers were Jamie Raskin, Diana DeGette, David Cicilline, Joaquin Castro, Eric Swalwell, Ted Lieu, Stacey Plaskett, Madeline Dean, and Joe Neguse.
question_details.fine_print:
\- The DOJ must publicly and officially announce the initiation of an investigation or prosecution against the individual.

\- The resolution does not require a conviction or final outcome—only the announcement of a formal investigation or prosecution.

\- For clarity, the question includes impeachment managers formally appointed for Trump’s impeachment proceedings and leadership roles active as of the time of the DOJ’s announcement.

\- Metaculus will resolve this question based on [<u>credible sources</u>](https://www.metaculus.com/faq/#definitions).

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**'An aura of criminality': NYT report exposes Trump prosecutions as a 'trophy' for MAGA**
According to a November 10, 2025, report by The New York Times, former President Donald Trump may not be pursuing convictions of political opponents with serious intent, but instead is using prosecutions to 'create an aura of criminality' around them as a symbolic 'trophy' for die-hard MAGA supporters. The report highlights that federal prosecutor Jason A. Reding Quiñones in the Southern District of Florida is expanding an investigation into a purported 'grand conspiracy' against Trump, issuing over two dozen subpoenas—including to former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper and former FBI agent Peter Strzok. The prosecution's central narrative—that 'deep state' Democrats conspired to undermine Trump’s 2016 campaign and presidency—remains 'unsupported by the evidence,' according to the NYT. The report concludes that while it is unclear whether the subpoenas will result in charges or convictions, the mere act of naming and shaming political foes serves as a symbolic victory for Trump’s base, who view such actions as a legitimate function of law enforcement.
Original language: en
Publish date: November 10, 2025 02:05 AM
Source:[Raw Story](https://www.rawstory.com/trump-2674280080/)

**How an Adam Schiff indictment could shake the Senate**
Sen. Adam Schiff (D-Calif.), a prominent figure in the first impeachment of President Donald Trump, is under investigation for alleged mortgage fraud, a charge he has denied. President Trump has publicly urged Attorney General Pam Bondi to pursue Schiff, following previous indictments of James Comey and Letitia James, marking a significant escalation in Trump’s campaign against political adversaries. The investigation remains ongoing, with reports suggesting prosecutors face difficulties gathering sufficient evidence. Schiff has launched a legal defense fund and is supported by a $8.6 million campaign war chest, with legal representation from WilmerHale and former U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara. Democrats are deeply concerned, fearing a precedent that could lead to widespread targeting of elected officials, while many Republicans remain silent or express discomfort. Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.) warned that the weaponization of the DOJ undermines the rule of law, and Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) criticized the lack of Republican opposition. Some Republicans, like Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.), openly support targeting Schiff, accusing him of misconduct during the first impeachment. Senate Judiciary Committee Chair Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) noted the case appears difficult to win, while the DOJ declined to comment. Schiff has not received direct outreach from GOP colleagues, but Democrats are preparing contingency plans, including legal readiness and defense infrastructure. The situation reflects heightened polarization and concerns over the politicization of justice.
Original language: en
Publish date: November 09, 2025 12:00 PM
Source:[Yahoo](https://www.yahoo.com/news/articles/adam-schiff-indictment-could-shake-120000903.html)

**GOP pushes to question Trump prosecutor Jack Smith quietly. What are they hiding? | Opinion - Yahoo News Canada**
Jack Smith, the special counsel appointed in 2022 to investigate Donald Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election and his retention of classified documents at Mar-a-Lago, released Volume I of his report two weeks before Trump’s 2024 inauguration, after the indictment against Trump was dropped due to DOJ protocols prohibiting prosecution of sitting presidents. Volume II, detailing the classified documents case, remains under a gag order imposed by U.S. District Judge Aileen Cannon, a Trump-appointed judge known for delaying proceedings against him. The 11th Circuit Court of Appeals, in a November 3 order, criticized Cannon for 'undue delay' and gave her 60 days to act on requests from American Oversight and the Knight First Amendment Institute to lift the gag order. Republicans in Congress, including House Judiciary Chair Jim Jordan and Senate Judiciary Chair Chuck Grassley, have demanded that Smith testify in private interviews. Smith’s legal team responded on October 23, stating he is willing to testify but requires guidance from the Department of Justice on disclosing grand jury information, including Volume II, and insists on an open hearing. Democrats have supported Smith’s call for transparency. Scott Wilkens of the Knight First Amendment Institute noted that public testimony could accelerate public access to Volume II. The standoff may extend into the 2026 midterm elections, with Trump opposing transparency as he seeks to rewrite the narrative around his post-2020 conduct. The article questions whether Republican demands for private testimony conceal an intent to avoid public scrutiny of Volume II.
Original language: en
Publish date: November 09, 2025 09:02 AM
Source:[Yahoo](https://ca.news.yahoo.com/gop-pushes-trump-prosecutor-jack-090226145.html)

**GOP pushes to question Trump prosecutor Jack Smith quietly. What are they hiding? | Opinion**
Republican lawmakers in Congress, including U.S. Rep. Jim Jordan and Sen. Chuck Grassley, have requested private testimony from special counsel Jack Smith regarding his investigation into Donald Trump’s conduct after the 2020 election, particularly concerning the hoarding of classified documents. Smith, through his legal team, has expressed willingness to testify but insists on an open hearing rather than a closed-door session, citing the need for guidance from the Department of Justice on disclosing federal grand jury information, including Volume II of his report. This volume, which details the classified documents case, remains under a gag order imposed by U.S. District Judge Aileen Cannon, a Trump appointee with a history of delaying proceedings against him. A three-judge panel from the 11th Circuit has ordered Cannon to act within 60 days on requests to lift the gag order, criticizing her for 'undue delay.' If Cannon delays until January, the case could be appealed to the 11th Circuit, and Trump may appeal to the U.S. Supreme Court. Democrats and advocacy groups like American Oversight and the Knight First Amendment Institute are pushing for transparency, arguing that public testimony could accelerate the release of Volume II. The author contends that Republicans’ demand for private hearings raises questions about what they might be hiding, especially since they claim to seek justice. The situation could extend into the 2026 midterm elections, with Trump likely opposing any public scrutiny that undermines his efforts to rewrite his post-2020 narrative. Scott Wilkens of the Knight First Amendment Institute emphasized that public testimony could provide faster access to critical information than the judicial process.

**Letitia James accuses Trump of 'vindictive' political animus in motion to dismiss fraud charges**
New York Attorney General Letitia James (D) filed a 50-page motion to dismiss federal fraud charges brought against her by the Trump administration, arguing the case stems from President Trump's 'vindictive and selective prosecution' rooted in political animus. The motion claims the indictment violates the Fifth Amendment, citing Trump’s repeated derogatory remarks—such as calling her 'SCUM,' 'a Complete and Total Disaster,' 'racist,' 'weak,' and 'a monster'—as evidence of unconstitutional targeting. James’s attorneys assert that the charges were triggered by her 2022 civil fraud investigation into Trump’s business empire, which resulted in a $354.8 million penalty (over $500 million with interest) before being overturned on appeal. The motion characterizes the DOJ’s actions as 'invidious and in bad faith,' alleging the department is 'too tainted with unconstitutional motivation' to prosecute fairly. James pleaded not guilty to bank fraud and making false statements related to her Virginia home mortgage, where she allegedly misrepresented her intent to use the property as a secondary residence, saving nearly $19,000. She has repeatedly denounced the charges as 'baseless' and part of a 'weaponizing of justice for political gain,' vowing to 'not bow, not break, not bend' at a rally for a mayoral candidate. The trial is scheduled for January 26, 2026. Alongside James, the DOJ indicted other perceived political opponents, including former FBI Director James Comey and former national security adviser John Bolton, who also pleaded not guilty. Trump denied the charges were politically motivated, claiming he was 'mild-mannered' and that the indictments were necessary to protect his ability to run for president, stating, 'Otherwise, I couldn't have run for president.'

**DOJ prepares subpoenas in sweeping criminal probe of Obama-era Trump-Russia investigation**
The U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) is preparing grand jury subpoenas as part of a sweeping criminal probe into the Obama-era investigation of Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election, according to sources familiar with the matter. The probe, led by Jason Reding Quiñones, U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida and a close associate of Attorney General Pam Bondi, targets former top officials from the Obama administration, including former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper and former CIA Director John Brennan. The subpoenas seek documents related to the 2016 Russia investigation, which began under President Barack Obama. The probe may extend beyond those involved in the original Russia inquiry to include Biden administration officials who investigated Donald Trump for mishandling classified documents and attempting to overturn the 2020 election. Former FBI Director James Comey, indicted on unrelated charges in September 2024 following Trump’s demands, is also under scrutiny, with his defense team preparing for potential inclusion. Trump has publicly called for prosecutions of figures including Adam Schiff, Jack Smith, Merrick Garland, Lisa Monaco, and Chris Wray, accusing them of a 'corrupt J-6 Witch Hunt.' Critics, including Democrats and former intelligence officials, argue the investigation is politically motivated and baseless, citing multiple bipartisan reviews—such as the Senate Intelligence Committee’s 2019 report—that confirmed Russian interference in 2016, though no conclusive evidence of campaign collusion was found. The DOJ has not commented. The Miami-based investigation is reportedly recruiting prosecutors and restructuring its national security unit, with a grand jury expected to convene in Fort Pierce, Florida, to avoid perceived Democratic bias in Washington, D.C. Republican lawmakers and Trump allies claim a 'treasonous conspiracy' by Obama and Biden officials, citing alleged politicization of intelligence, including the use of the Steele dossier. However, the DOJ’s own special counsel John Durham found no criminal wrongdoing in the original investigation. The probe marks Trump’s most ambitious effort to weaponize federal law enforcement against perceived political adversaries.
Original language: en
Publish date: November 08, 2025 01:41 AM
Source:[Yahoo](https://www.yahoo.com/news/articles/doj-prepares-subpoenas-sweeping-criminal-014139441.html)

**If Arctic Frost Perpetrators Don't Go To Jail, Conservatives Will**
The article claims that the Biden Administration's 'Arctic Frost' operation, led by Attorney General Merrick Garland and Special Counsel Jack Smith, was a partisan, illegal effort to surveil and prosecute the Republican Party under the guise of investigating January 6th. According to the article, Smith secretly surveilled at least eight Republican senators without probable cause, issued 197 subpoenas to 430 individuals and organizations—many unrelated to January 6th or even non-existent at the time—and demanded access to private donor data, banking records, and media contacts. The subpoenas were accompanied by gag orders preventing phone companies from informing senators, a move alleged to be a federal crime. Despite spending millions in legal fees, the investigation yielded no evidence of wrongdoing. The article argues that if Donald Trump had not won the 2024 election, the operation would have continued, potentially leading to indictments, de-banking, and arrests of conservative figures under a future Democratic administration. It asserts that the perpetrators—DOJ prosecutors, FBI agents, and judges—remain in their positions and are emboldened, not deterred, by past actions. The article calls on Republicans to respond with severe legal consequences: congressional hearings, disbarment, impeachment, prosecution, imprisonment, and pension forfeiture for those involved in Arctic Frost. It frames this not as revenge, but as necessary justice to deter future abuses of power by Democratic elites, warning that without such action, the Republican Party risks existential threat. The article concludes that the only remaining restraint on Democrat power is fear, and that Republicans must enforce the rule of law to restore balance.
Original language: en
Publish date: November 06, 2025 12:17 PM
Source:[The Federalist](https://thefederalist.com/2025/11/06/if-arctic-frost-perpetrators-dont-go-to-jail-conservatives-will/)

**Judge Questions Justice Department’s Approach in Comey Prosecution**
Federal magistrate judge William Fitzpatrick of the Eastern District of Virginia issued a rare public warning to the Justice Department (DOJ) on November 5, 2025, suggesting that prosecutors in the criminal case against former FBI Director James Comey may have mishandled evidence and prioritized indictment over thorough investigation. During a brief hearing, Fitzpatrick stated, 'Right now, we are in a bit of a feeling of indict first, investigate later,' marking an unusual judicial rebuke of DOJ procedures. The remark underscores internal concerns within the DOJ, with multiple career prosecutors reportedly questioning the case’s merit and timing. Critics allege the prosecution is politically motivated, targeting Comey—whose 2017 dismissal by former President Donald Trump sparked obstruction allegations—during a sensitive period in U.S. politics. The Eastern District of Virginia, a common venue for national security cases due to its proximity to Washington, D.C., has drawn defense scrutiny over potential jury bias. Legal experts note that such judicial warnings often precede serious consequences, including evidence exclusion or dismissal of charges. The DOJ has not yet publicly responded to the judge’s concerns. The defense may now file motions challenging the adequacy of the pre-indictment investigation, potentially delaying trial proceedings. The case raises broader questions about judicial oversight and prosecutorial accountability in high-profile, politically charged prosecutions.
Original language: en
Publish date: November 05, 2025 08:45 PM
Source:[The Dupree Report](https://www.thedupreereport.com/2025/11/judge-warns-doj-comey/)

**Judge scolds Comey prosecutors, orders records to be produced**
U.S. Magistrate Judge William Fitzpatrick ordered prosecutors to provide grand jury records and evidence from the investigation into former FBI Director James Comey by the end of Thursday, November 6, 2025, criticizing the Department of Justice (DOJ) for 'indict first and investigate later.' Comey, who was present at the hearing but did not speak, and his lawyers stated they had not seen the materials, prompting the judge to declare, 'We're going to fix that, and we're going to fix that today.' The materials include communications between Comey and Columbia University law professor Daniel Richman, a special government employee at the FBI, seized in 2019 and 2020. Prosecutors allege Comey encouraged Richman to speak with reporters and lied to Congress about authorizing anonymous sources. Comey pleaded not guilty last month to charges related to false testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee in 2020, where he claimed he did not authorize a media leak about the FBI's investigation into Hillary Clinton and the Trump-Russia probe. The DOJ defended President Trump's social media posts calling for Comey's prosecution, asserting they were not retaliatory, while Comey's lawyers argued the case is politically motivated and a departure from the DOJ's traditional ethical standards. Trump had used Truth Social to call for the prosecution of Comey, New York Attorney General Letitia James, and former national security advisor John Bolton, all of whom have since been indicted. Comey's legal team emphasized that the DOJ has historically followed only facts and law, and this case represents a sharp break from that tradition. The trial is scheduled to begin on January 5, 2026.
Original language: en
Publish date: November 05, 2025 05:52 PM
Source:[The Hill](https://thehill.com/regulation/court-battles/5591009-court-requests-records-james-comey-indictment/)

**Critics were right about Merrick Garland — and this new book proves it**
MSNBC’s Ken Dilanian reviewed an advanced copy of the book *Injustice: How Politics and Fear Vanquished America’s Justice Department* by Carol Leonnig and Aaron Davis, which criticizes former U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland’s handling of two high-profile cases involving Donald Trump after the 2020 election: the investigation into classified documents found at Trump’s Florida mansion and the probe into the fake electors scheme to overturn Joe Biden’s victory. According to the book, Garland’s decision-making was marked by excessive caution, a desire to avoid setting legal precedents, and a freeze on both cases before the 2022 midterms—even though Trump was not on the ballot and had not yet declared his 2024 candidacy. Dilanian reports that these delays, driven by a 'conservative interpretation' of DOJ policies, may have hampered federal criminal investigations. While Dilanian acknowledges that Garland’s critics on the right were wrong to claim the Justice Department was weaponized against Trump, he argues that Garland’s actions were still problematic, as they prioritized the appearance of impartiality and political optics over justice. The author of the article contends that Garland’s choices were influenced by fear of backlash from rightwing media and political pressure, even if no direct White House interference occurred. The delays allowed the U.S. Supreme Court to strike down Colorado’s decision to bar Trump from the ballot under the 14th Amendment, effectively removing a legal check on Trump before the 2024 election. The article warns that this precedent enables powerful figures to act with impunity, and argues that Dilanian’s portrayal of Garland as having done 'things right' is misleading—it reflects a political bias that downplays Garland’s failure to prioritize justice over image. The piece concludes that future accountability efforts must learn from Garland’s mistakes and that systemic reforms—such as abolishing ICE or expanding the Supreme Court—are necessary to prevent future democratic erosion.
Original language: en
Publish date: November 04, 2025 03:00 PM
Source:[Alternet](https://www.alternet.org/alternet-exclusives/criticism-of-merrick-garland/)

**DOJ defends Trump Truth Social post as Comey seeks to have case dismissed**
The Department of Justice (DOJ) defended the federal case against former FBI Director James Comey in a 48-page filing, urging a court to reject his motion to dismiss the indictment. Comey, indicted in late September on charges of making false statements and obstructing a congressional investigation, pleaded not guilty. His legal team argued that the prosecution was vindictive and selective, citing President Donald Trump’s September Truth Social post calling for the prosecution of political adversaries—including Comey, Sen. Adam Schiff, and New York Attorney General Letitia James—as evidence of political bias. The DOJ countered that Trump’s post reflected his personal views on the need for prosecution but did not constitute direct evidence of a vindictive motive. Prosecutors emphasized that the decision to prosecute was made by DOJ officials, not the President, and that there was no direct admission of discriminatory intent. They dismissed Comey’s claims as requiring 'leaps of logic and a big dose of cynicism.' Additionally, Comey’s team challenged the validity of interim U.S. Attorney Lindsey Halligan’s appointment, arguing it was unconstitutional and unlawful, since she was Trump’s former personal attorney and replaced Erik Siebert, who resigned under pressure to indict Comey and James. The DOJ maintained that Halligan’s appointment complied with federal law and the Constitution’s Appointments Clause. The case has sparked intense political reactions nationwide.
Original language: en
Publish date: November 04, 2025 01:18 PM
Source:[Fox News](https://www.foxnews.com/politics/doj-defends-trump-truth-social-post-comey-seeks-have-case-dismissed)

**Justice Department defends Trump's post as it urges judge to reject Comey's effort to dismiss case**
The U.S. Justice Department urged a federal judge to reject James Comey’s claim that his prosecution is politically motivated retribution, arguing that Comey has failed to provide direct evidence of a vindictive motive by President Donald Trump. Prosecutors defended Trump’s September 2020 social media post calling for action against Comey, stating it reflects a 'legitimate prosecutorial motive' rather than political spite. They emphasized that the decision to prosecute was made by DOJ officials, not the president, and dismissed Comey’s argument as requiring 'leaps of logic and a big dose of cynicism.' The case centers on Comey’s indictment for allegedly lying to Congress on September 30, 2020, regarding whether he authorized FBI leaks to the media about investigations involving Trump and Hillary Clinton. Prosecutors cited communications between Comey and Daniel Richman, a Columbia University law professor, to support the claim that Comey encouraged media disclosures. Comey’s defense argues the Senate questions from Senator Ted Cruz were vague and ambiguous, specifically referencing Andrew McCabe, not Richman, making it impossible for Comey to have intended to lie. Additionally, Comey’s lawyers are challenging the appointment of Lindsey Halligan, a White House aide with no prior federal prosecution experience, as U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia after Erik Siebert’s resignation under administration pressure. The defense has also requested access to grand jury transcripts and audio recordings, alleging factual and legal errors may have influenced the indictment. The case is one of several high-profile challenges to the prosecution, with New York Attorney General Letitia James’s legal team signaling it may make a similar argument.
Original language: en
Publish date: November 03, 2025 11:11 PM
Source:[AP](https://apnews.com/article/justice-department-james-comey-donald-trump-107b753d133f756a469ee65f48aa9e17)

**New documents expose Biden DOJ's 'fishing expedition' into Trump, Republicans during 2024 race**
New whistleblower documents released on October 29, 2025, reveal that the Biden Justice Department, under Special Prosecutor Jack Smith, launched a broad investigative operation codenamed 'Arctic Frost' targeting the Republican Party shortly after Donald Trump announced his 2024 presidential campaign in November 2022. The operation issued 197 subpoenas to over 430 individuals and organizations, including high-profile figures such as Stephen Miller, Dan Scavino, Jared Kushner, and Lara Trump, as well as banks, media outlets like CBS and Fox News, and 11 members of Congress whose phone records were secretly subpoenaed. One subpoena to AT&T for Senator Ted Cruz’s cell phone records was denied due to constitutional protections, but the company was silenced by a secret court order from Judge James Boasberg, who cited risks of evidence tampering and witness intimidation. Cruz publicly waived the gag order and denounced the order as a weaponization of the judiciary, calling for Boasberg’s impeachment. Republican senators, including Charles E. Grassley and Lindsey Graham, condemned the probe as a 'fishing expedition' and an abuse of power, arguing it was politically motivated and targeted Republicans solely because of Trump’s campaign. Graham claimed the investigation was a 'Democratic machine' effort to derail Trump’s political comeback. Smith, who indicted Trump on August 1, 2023, for election interference related to the 2020 election, maintains his decision was justified, stating Trump made 'knowingly false claims of election fraud' and that he would have been convicted had Trump not won re-election. The indictment was dismissed after Trump’s 2024 victory. The House has demanded full disclosure of Arctic Frost documents before considering Smith’s testimony, and Republicans are urging further whistleblowers to come forward.
Original language: en
Publish date: October 29, 2025 05:30 PM
Source:[Washington Times](https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2025/oct/29/new-documents-expose-biden-dojs-fishing-expedition-trump-republicans/)

**Democrats Must Be Punished for Their Lawfare**
The article claims that the Democratic Party systematically engages in 'lawfare'—using the legal system to target political opponents, particularly Donald Trump and his associates. **White House admits Trump's message to Bondi to prosecute enemies was supposed to be a DM: report**
A September 20, 2025, post by Donald Trump on Truth Social, addressed to Attorney General Pam Bondi and urging immediate prosecution of his perceived political enemies—including former FBI Director James Comey—was intended as a private direct message (DM), according to White House officials. Trump believed he had sent the message directly to Bondi, but it was publicly posted, prompting surprise and backlash. The post, which accused Comey, New York Attorney General Letitia James, and Senator Adam Schiff of being 'all guilty as hell' and demanded 'justice be served' after Trump's 'impeachments and indictments,' was later followed by a corrective message praising Bondi's work. The incident highlights a significant shift in the Department of Justice, now reportedly stripped of independence under Trump and Bondi. Comey, who pleaded not guilty to lying to Congress and obstruction, faces a trial tentatively scheduled for January 5, 2026, with his attorneys planning to challenge the case on grounds of Trump's 'vindictive' prosecution. The post is expected to be central to that motion, demonstrating presidential direction to prosecute a target labeled 'guilty' before charges were filed. The administration has removed dozens of officials deemed disloyal, including Erik Siebert, the former U.S. Attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia, whom Trump fired for refusing to pursue Comey. Trump then nominated Lindsey Halligan, a lawyer with no prosecutorial experience, to replace him. Halligan, in a rare move, personally presented the case to a grand jury, which indicted Comey on two counts—false statements to Congress and obstruction—after only 14 of 23 jurors voted in favor. Internal prosecutors had previously cited difficulties due to a key witness, Columbia law professor Daniel Richmond, whose testimony would create 'likely insurmountable problems' for the case. Bondi, during her January confirmation hearing, pledged to end the 'weaponization' of the Justice Department, echoing Trump’s claims that his indictments were politically motivated. When questioned again in a Senate hearing, she refused to confirm whether she received White House instructions. The administration is also targeting other Democratic figures and progressive groups, including former national security adviser John Bolton, whose home was raided in August and who may face charges in Maryland. Former FBI Director Christopher Wray is also under investigation, though the focus remains unclear.
